thoughts: Plain letter “a” in French is almost always the same open vowel, so English speakers just have to remember to keep it short and pure. The sound occurs anywhere in a word and is found in many loan-words they already know.
description: A short, open “ah” sound, similar to the first vowel in English “father,” but kept shorter and without the glide some Americans add. Mouth opens wide, tongue low and front-central.

thoughts: French “b” is basically the same voiced bilabial stop as English “b” (as in “bat”). The only twist is that a final -b can be silent in a handful of old-fashioned words such as “plomb.” Otherwise you just release your lips and let the vocal cords vibrate, exactly like English.
description: Usually pronounced just like the English “b” in “boy.” Lips come together, vocal cords vibrate, then the lips release. A final written -b is sometimes silent in a few set words (e.g., plomb /plɔ̃/), but this is rare.

thoughts: French “c” is not a new sound for English speakers—it is either the hard “k” or the soft “s” they already know. The only thing to learn is the spelling rule that triggers each value.
description: The letter c in French has two main pronunciations: (1) a hard k sound, like English “kite,” when it appears before a, o, u, or another consonant; (2) a soft s sound, like English “snake,” when it appears before e, i, or y. Unlike English, French never uses c for the “ch” sound by itself (that requires ch or ç).

thoughts: The French letter “d” is almost the same stop consonant English speakers already use, but it’s made with the tongue a little farther forward (against the upper teeth) and without the tiny puff of air English often adds. Final “d” is normally silent unless there’s liaison. Overall, very familiar and easy for English speakers.
description: Dental, unaspirated /d/. Tip of the tongue touches the upper teeth (not the ridge), then releases without a burst of air. At the end of a word it is usually silent, unless followed by a vowel in liaison (e.g., “grand hôtel”).

thoughts: French “e” covers three main sounds: closed [e] (similar to the vowel in English “day” but shorter, no glide), open [ɛ] (like the vowel in “bet”), and the neutral schwa [ə] (a very quick, relaxed “uh” that can disappear). English already has comparable vowels, but knowing which one to use—and when the schwa drops—takes practice.
description:
Depending on spelling and stress, plain “e” in French can be:
• Closed [e] – short, tense “ay” as in English “day” (but don’t add a final y-glide). Often written é, or in final ‑er endings.
• Open [ɛ] – like the “e” in “bet.” Common before double consonants or in words like “merci.”
• Schwa [ə] – a quick, relaxed “uh,” often in small words like “le” or the second syllable of “parle.” In casual speech it may disappear entirely.

thoughts: The French letter “f” is pronounced exactly like the English “f.” English speakers already meet it in everyday loan-words such as “café” and “chef,” so there is no new mouth position to learn. The only quick reminder: in French, the letter is almost always pronounced, even at the end of a word (unlike many other French consonants).
description: Same sound as the English “f” in “fun”: voiceless, made by letting air pass between the upper teeth and lower lip. Keep the airflow steady; do not add vocal-cord vibration.

thoughts: French “g” has two pronunciations an English speaker must notice: the hard [g] (as in English “go”) and the soft [ʒ] (as in the s-sound of “measure”). The letter’s sound is fixed by the vowel that follows, so learners need to watch the spelling, not guess from English.
description:
• Hard g: Before a, o, u, or a consonant, it is the same hard ‘g’ you hear at the start of English “go.”
• Soft g: Before e, i, or y, it becomes the French /ʒ/, like the ‘s’ in English “measure.”
• The combo “gu-e/i” (baguette, guitare) keeps the hard [g]; the u is silent.
Tip: For the soft /ʒ/, keep the tongue high and slightly forward; don’t let the tip touch the teeth, and make a buzzing airflow, not a stop.

thoughts: French “h” is almost always silent, so the main issue for English speakers is remembering NOT to breathe out a /h/ sound. That is fairly easy to do, because English already has a few silent-h words (hour, honor). The only extra wrinkle is the linguistic distinction between “h muet” (allows liaison) and “h aspiré” (blocks liaison), but that does not change how you actually pronounce it—both are silent—so it is more a listening/grammar point than a pronunciation one.
description: In French, the letter “h” is never pronounced as an audible /h/ like in English “hat.” You simply start the next vowel or consonant without any burst of air. The mouth stays relaxed; no voiceless puff is made. Remember: silent, with or without liaison depending on the word, but always silent for pronunciation.

thoughts: French “i” is almost always the pure vowel [i]—the tight, forward “ee” sound in English “see,” but shorter and without the English-style diphthong glide. When it comes right before another vowel (as in “fiancé”), it usually turns into a quick consonant-like glide [j] (similar to the English ‘y’ in “yes”). Because English already has an “ee” sound and a ‘y’ glide, this letter poses little novelty for most learners.
description: Say a short, crisp “ee,” keeping the tongue high and forward, lips spread (no rounding). Avoid letting it slide into two sounds (no “ee-uh”). Before another vowel it becomes a fast ‘y’ sound, as in “fiancé” [fya-].

thoughts: French “j” is almost always pronounced /ʒ/, the same sound English speakers hear in the middle of “viSION” or “garaGE”.  English has the sound but never spells it with the letter “j”, so learners must break the link between English “j” (/dʒ/) and French “j” (/ʒ/).  The sound carries the voice; don’t add a stop or “d” in front of it.
description: Pronounce French “j” as the soft, voiced “zh” sound (/ʒ/), like the middle of English “viSION”.  Lips relaxed, vocal cords vibrating, air flows smoothly—no tongue tip tap as in English “j” (/dʒ/).  It stays the same before any vowel.

thoughts: /k/ in French is basically the same unvoiced hard “k” English speakers know, but it’s produced with almost no burst of air (little or no aspiration). Because the mouth movement and tongue placement match English, the sound is very familiar.
description: A hard, voiceless “k” sound made at the back of the mouth, like the first sound in English “cat,” but with less puff of air. Keep the back of the tongue against the soft palate, release cleanly, and avoid aspirating strongly.

thoughts: French uses only a “clear L” (tongue tip on the ridge just behind the upper teeth, air flows along the sides). English speakers already know this sound at the start of words ("light"), but English often makes a dark, velarized L at the ends of syllables ("feel"). In French you must keep it light/clear everywhere, including word-finally.
description: Always a clear, light L. Touch the tip of your tongue to the alveolar ridge and let the sides of the tongue lower slightly; do NOT pull the back of the tongue up the way many English speakers do in words like “ball.” The sound stays the same at the beginning, middle, or end of French words.

thoughts: English speakers already use the voiced bilabial nasal [m] every day, so this sound itself is nothing new. The only mild trap in French spelling is that an "m" after a vowel can sometimes be silent and simply mark a nasal vowel (e.g., in "faim"), but as a consonant it is produced exactly like English "m."
description: Pronounced like the English "m" in “mother”: close your lips, let the sound resonate through your nose, and keep the vocal cords vibrating. Same mouth position, same voicing. Just remember that when "m" follows a vowel and isn’t followed by another vowel, it often makes the vowel nasal and may not be pronounced as a separate consonant.

thoughts: English speakers already know the basic [n] sound; the only new idea is that in French a final or before-consonant “n” usually isn’t pronounced at all – it just nasalises the vowel before it.
description: 1) As a regular n-sound [n] when it starts a word, sits between two vowels, or is doubled (nn). Your tongue touches the ridge just behind your upper teeth – exactly like the English n in “no”. 2) Silent but nasalises the vowel before it when it comes before another consonant or ends the word: the air comes out of your nose but you do NOT add a separate n-sound. Think of saying the vowel while humming through your nose, then stopping – e.g. “bon” ends on a nasalised “aw̃” rather than “bawn”.

thoughts: English speakers already know the written letter “o,” and the French sound is in the same general mouth-area. The main surprise is that French has two versions: a ‘closed’ pure /o/ (lips rounded, tongue high-mid, no English-style diphthong) and a more ‘open’ /ɔ/ (jaw a bit lower, like the vowel in some accents’ “thought”). No glide is added, and length is shorter than English long O. Learners must resist turning it into the “oh-oo” diphthong.
description: French “o” is either:  • closed /o/ – like the first part of English “go” but without the trailing glide; lips rounded, tongue mid-high.  • open /ɔ/ – similar to British English “off/aw,” mouth slightly more open.  Which one you hear depends on spelling patterns and surrounding letters, but both stay pure and short.

thoughts: The French letter “p” is the same voiceless bilabial plosive English speakers already know, but in French it is released with little or no puff of air (no strong aspiration). Because the basic mouth position is identical to English, most learners have no trouble—only the reduced burst of air may feel slightly softer than in words like English “peach.”
description: Like the English “p” in “spin” rather than the strongly-aspirated “p” in “pin.” Lips come together, build a small pressure, then release cleanly with almost no extra breath.

thoughts: French “q” is almost always written as the digraph “qu”.  It simply represents the hard K sound /k/, never the English /kw/.  The only trick is to remember that the following “u” is purely spelling—your lips do not round for a W.
description: Pronounce “qu” exactly like the K in English “skip”.  Do NOT add a W-glide as in English “queen”.  The written “u” is silent unless it carries its own written accent (rare).  Word-final “que” is also /k/.

thoughts: French “r” is written with the same letter English speakers know, so it looks familiar. The sound itself, however, is produced far back in the throat (a voiced uvular fricative), something English never uses. Learners must keep the tip of the tongue down and let the back of the tongue lightly rub against the uvula while voicing—almost like a gentle gargle. Because it is so different from the English alveolar ‘r’, it usually takes sustained practice to master.
description: The French “r” is a throaty, voiced uvular fricative /ʁ/. Instead of curling the tongue like in English, keep the tip low, raise the back of the tongue toward the uvula, and let air pass with slight vibration. Think of a soft, voiced version of the throaty sound you make when clearing your throat.

thoughts: French “s” is rarely a new mouth-shape for English speakers – it is either the familiar unvoiced /s/, its equally familiar voiced cousin /z/, or completely silent at the end of certain words. The challenge is rule-based spelling, not articulation.
description: In French a single “s” between vowels becomes the voiced /z/ (like the z in “lazy”). A single “s” at the start of a word, before a consonant, or followed by a consonant stays the unvoiced /s/ (like the s in “sun”). A double “ss” is always the sharp /s/. A final written “s” is often silent unless liaison makes it link to a following vowel.

thoughts: English speakers already know the basic /t/ sound, but in French they must remember the lack of aspiration, that many final t’s are silent, and that “ti” before a vowel often sounds like /s/ or /sj/.
description: Usually the same crisp /t/ as in English but with almost no puff of air (unaspirated). At the end of words it is often silent unless followed by a mute-e (e.g., tar-te). In “ti + vowel” the t typically softens to an /s/-like sound: na-sion. Learn to release it quickly and close to the teeth.

thoughts: French “u” is almost always the single vowel /y/ – a sound English doesn’t have. Speakers must round their lips as for “oo” in “food” while keeping the tongue high and forward as for “ee” in “see.” Because English lacks this exact vowel, learners often substitute /u/ or /ɪ/. The letter can appear anywhere in a word and keeps the same quality, even with a circumflex (û). It is NOT the same as the digraph “ou.”
description: Pronounce it as a tight-lipped, fronted “oo.” Say English “ee,” freeze the tongue, then round the lips. It is a single, pure vowel, always short and tense.

thoughts: French v is essentially the same voiced “v” sound English speakers already use (as in “van”). Little to explain beyond reminding learners to keep the lower lip lightly against the upper teeth and make the sound voiced; do not touch the tongue to the teeth like the English “th.”
description: Voiced labiodental fricative, just like the English v in “violin.” Press lower lip gently against upper front teeth and make it voiced; no extra puff of air.

thoughts: Letter “w” is uncommon in native French words; it appears mostly in borrowings.  Native speakers treat it in two ways: either like the English /w/ sound, or—especially in older or very Gallicised words—like a /v/.  English learners therefore mainly have to remember which value each borrowed word has.
description: Two possible pronunciations: (1) /w/ – just like the English “w” in “we.”  This is heard in recent loan-words and tech terms (web, week-end, kiwi).  Keep the lips rounded and glide quickly into the following vowel.  (2) /v/ – a voiced “v” as in English “van.”  This older, Gallicised value occurs in words such as “wagon” or “watt.”  There’s no reliable spelling rule; you memorise word by word.

thoughts: The letter “x” in French is unpredictable: it can be silent, /s/, /ks/, or /gz/ depending on position and word origin. Learners need to memorize common patterns and examples.
description:
1) Most often between vowels or before a consonant it sounds like English “ks” (as in “books”).
2) At the very start of a word it is usually /gz/ (a quick “gz” like “eggs” without the first e).
3) At the end of many common number-words it becomes /s/ (dix, six). 
4) In several small function words it is completely silent but still affects the preceding vowel (deux, faux, yeux).

thoughts: French “y” is almost always read as the pure vowel /i/ (like the “ee” in English “see”), not the English diphthong /aɪ/.  After another vowel it simply begins a second syllable and may be heard as a quick glide /j/ (ma-yo-).  The sound itself is easy; the only trap for English speakers is resisting the urge to say /aɪ/.
description: Pronounce the letter “y” as a clean, short “ee” sound /i/.  When it comes right after another vowel you will glide from the first vowel into this /i/ (written “ay”, “oy”, etc.), but do NOT turn it into the English “y” in “my.”

thoughts: French “z” is very straightforward for English speakers: the sound is the same voiced hissing found in English “zoo.” The only surprise is that a final written “z” is normally silent—unless liaison wakes it up before a following vowel, when it links just like the English phrase “rose is.”
description: Usually the same /z/ you hear in English “zoo.” Keep the tongue close to your upper teeth and let your vocal cords buzz. When the letter is the last letter of a word, it is almost always silent in careful speech, though it re-appears as a linking /z/ when the next word begins with a vowel (liaison).

thoughts: French “à” is simply the open ‘ah’ sound English speakers already make in words like “spa.” The accent mainly serves spelling/meaning purposes, not a special pronunciation, so the sound itself feels very familiar.

thoughts: English speakers already know the base vowel sound /a/ (as in British “spa”), and that is essentially what â represents. The main novelty is the little ‘roof’ accent (circonflexe), which does NOT change the sound much in modern French—just makes it a slightly longer, tenser version of plain a. So the challenge is minimal: keep the mouth open, tongue low and front-central, don’t turn it into the English diphthong of “cat.”
description: â is pronounced like a pure, open “ah” (IPA [a]) similar to the vowel in British English “spa” or the first part of American “father,” but a touch longer/tenser. Do NOT glide toward an ‘ee’ or ‘uh.’

thoughts: The trema on a (ä) is vanishingly rare in French; when it turns up it is almost always in brand names or other proper nouns borrowed from German or Scandinavian languages.  In standard French spelling the trema simply signals that the vowel is pronounced on its own, so for ä you still say the normal open French a (/a/, like the a in English “father”).  Because most encounters with ä happen in foreign names, many French speakers themselves approximate the German-style sound /ɛ/ (like the e in English “bet”).  Either way, an English speaker already knows both of those mouth positions, so the sound itself is not hard—recognising that it is even used in French is the surprising part.
description: In French the letter ä means the vowel a is pronounced separately from any vowel just before it.  The safest French realisation is the regular open a (/a/, as in “father”).  When the word is a borrowed German name, French often leans toward the German pronunciation /ɛ/ (as in English “bet”).  Either way, keep the tongue low and relaxed; do NOT glide into a w or y sound afterward.

thoughts: The letter “è” is just the open-mid front vowel /ɛ/ – basically the same vowel English speakers use in “bet.”  The accent grave mainly tells you two things: use the pure short ‘eh’ sound (never the long ‘ay’ /e/) and keep the syllable open, no trailing glide.  So for an English speaker the sound itself is familiar; the challenge is only remembering to keep it short and pure every time they see the grave accent.
description: Say a quick, relaxed “eh” like the e in English “bet” or “get,” but slightly more rounded lips and with no ending y-glide.  Keep it short and steady: one clear vowel, no diphthong.

thoughts: English speakers already have the /ɛ/ vowel (as in “bet”), so the French ê sound usually feels familiar. The main issue is remembering that it is a pure vowel (no trailing ‘y-glide’ like English “day”) and that the circumflex does not change the quality compared with è; it just marks spelling history. Because it shows up anywhere in a word, learners mainly need to watch the written accent and keep the vowel short and open.
description: Pronounce ê as the open "eh" sound /ɛ/, like the vowel in English “bet,” but keep it pure and a bit shorter. Do NOT let it slide toward “ay.” Lips stay relaxed, tongue mid-low at the front.

thoughts: ë is rare but shows up in a handful of well-known French words and brand names. The dieresis simply tells you to pronounce the letter e on its own instead of blending it with the vowel before it. English speakers already have the basic /ɛ/ sound (“eh” as in ‘bet’), so the main challenge is remembering to break the syllable.
description: ë is pronounced like a clear, short “eh” sound (IPA [ɛ] – similar to the e in English “bet”). The two dots mean you must start a new syllable: the e is not silent and does not combine with the preceding vowel. Say the preceding vowel, make a tiny break, then say “eh.”

thoughts: The circumflex over i does not change the vowel quality in modern standard French; it is still the close front vowel /i/—the same sound as the English “ee” in “see.” So learners only have to remember that the little hat is mainly a spelling/history marker, not a cue for a new sound.
description: Pronounce î exactly like the English long “ee” sound in “see” or “machine.” Keep the tongue high and forward, lips spread. Don’t try to lengthen or diphthong-ize it as some English dialects do; aim for a pure steady vowel.

thoughts: English speakers already know the plain French "i" sound (like the long “ee” in English "see"). The trema (¨) on ï does NOT change that quality; it only tells you to pronounce the ï as its own syllable instead of merging it with the vowel before it. So the sound is familiar; the only new info is the syllable break.
description: ï is the regular French /i/ sound (close to English “ee”), but the two dots signal that it starts a new syllable instead of forming a diphthong with the previous vowel. Think “na-EEV” for « naïve » or “ha-EE-tee” for « Haïti ». Keep the vowels separate and short; don’t blend them.

thoughts: French “ô” is simply the closed, pure /o/ vowel. English speakers often turn an “o” into a diphthong like the start of “oh-w,” so they must remember to keep it short and steady.
description: Pronounce it as a single, rounded "oh" sound, similar to the first part of English “oh” but without sliding toward a “w.” Lips are rounded; tongue is mid-high toward the back. It is the same quality you hear in the British pronunciation of “law” but a bit higher and tenser.

thoughts: The letter ö is extremely rare in modern French; when it does appear, the two dots (tréma) simply tell you to pronounce this particular “o” as a separate syllable, not to blend it with the following vowel. In other words, just say a normal French closed /o/ (similar to the “o” in English “go,” but without the glide) and then move on to the next vowel.
description: Say a pure French “o” (lips rounded, no glide) and then immediately pronounce the next vowel as its own syllable. Do NOT use the German ‘ö’ sound (/ø/)—French ö is still a plain /o/. The tréma only means “pronounce this vowel separately.”

thoughts: The grave-accented “ù” is very rare in French; it mainly appears in the words “où” (where) and “août” (August). The accent does not change the sound compared with a plain “u” – it still uses the French front-rounded vowel /y/. The accent only distinguishes spelling/meaning from similar words. English has no native /y/ vowel, so the main challenge is shaping the lips as for “oo” while keeping the tongue forward as for “ee.”
description: Pronounce it as the French vowel /y/: round your lips as if saying the English “oo” in “food,” but simultaneously keep the tongue high and forward like the “ee” in “see.” The grave accent does not alter the sound—only the spelling.

thoughts: English speakers almost never see a û in their own language, so the character itself is unfamiliar. Pronunciation-wise, however, it is just the regular French /y/ sound (spelled u or û). The circumflex does not change the sound; it usually marks where an old letter (often an s) used to be. /y/ is absent from standard English, so learners must master the “tight-lipped ‘ee’ ” position: say English “ee” in “see” while rounding the lips as if to say “oo.” Because it is the same sound as plain French u, the only real challenge is producing that front-rounded vowel at all.
description: û is pronounced exactly like the regular French letter “u”: a front-rounded vowel /y/. To English ears it sits between “ee” in ‘see’ and “oo” in ‘soon’: keep the tongue forward as for ‘ee’ but round the lips as for ‘oo.’ The circumflex (ˆ) does NOT affect the sound; it just signals historical spelling changes.

thoughts: French “ü” is extremely rare. It only appears when a diaeresis (tréma) sits on the letter u to show that the u must be pronounced as a separate vowel /y/ instead of being silent inside the digraph “gu.” Native English speech has no exact equivalent of /y/ (a tight, rounded “ee”), so both hearing and producing it can be tricky. Because the spelling is old-fashioned or limited to a few words and proper names, most English speakers have barely encountered it.
description: Pronounce it the same as the regular French u: keep your tongue in the English “ee” position while rounding your lips as for “oo.” The dieresis simply tells you to say the u at all, instead of letting it disappear after g.

thoughts: The letter ÿ is extremely rare in modern French and only shows up in a handful of proper names (mostly place names connected with Champagne wines). It is simply the letter “y” marked with a tréma to insist that it be pronounced as its own vowel sound, not blended with the vowel before it. The underlying sound is just the regular French /i/ (close to the English “ee” in “see”), so the sound itself is easy; the only thing unusual for an English speaker is seeing the dotted y.
description: ÿ = y with a diaeresis.  It tells you to pronounce the y as a separate syllable, usually like a short, pure “ee” sound (/i/), immediately after the preceding vowel.  Think “ah-ee” said quickly for “aÿ.”  It is not the German ü sound and it isn’t blended with the vowel before it.

thoughts: English speakers have seen this squiggly-bottomed c in words like “façade.” It simply forces the letter c to be said like an s before the vowels a, o, or u, where a plain c would normally sound like k. There’s no new mouth position—just remember it’s an s, not a k.
description: The letter “ç” (called a c-cedilla) is always pronounced like the English “s” in “see,” even though it appears before the vowels a, o, or u, where a regular c would be hard (k). Think of it as a visual reminder to soften the c.

thoughts: English has no native front-rounded vowels, so most learners have never had to pronounce the sound spelled with the ligature “œ.”  It sounds a bit like the English “uh” in “up,” but with the lips rounded as if you were starting to say “o.”  Because front-rounded vowels don’t exist in English, the sound feels unfamiliar and tends to drift toward either “uh” (unrounded) or “er” (as in “bird”) unless the learner pays close attention to lip shape.
description: French œ is a single vowel: a front, rounded "uh" sound.  Start with the short English "uh" in “cup,” but keep your tongue forward (like for “e”) while rounding your lips (like for “o”).  Your mouth should feel as if you’re saying the start of “sir” while whistling an “o” shape.

description: Pronounce æ just like the regular French open or closed e sound: somewhere between the English “e” in “bet” (/ɛ/) and the “ay” in “day” (/e/), without the final glide. In practice, say a clean, pure “eh/ay” vowel and you’ll be understood.

thoughts: French “h” never carries the audible /h/ sound that English speakers make.  There are two silent types: • h muet – acts as if the word began with a vowel, allowing elision/liaison (l’hôtel). • h aspiré – still silent but blocks elision/liaison (le hamburger).  The main challenge for English speakers is to resist adding a breathy /h/ at the start and to memorize which words permit or block liaison.
description: Always silent.  Keep your mouth relaxed and start straight with the following vowel or consonant—no puff of air.  Remember: some words behave like they start with a vowel (hôtel), others like they start with a consonant (hamburger), but in both cases you do NOT pronounce an /h/.

thoughts: French “h” is almost always silent, so the main issue for English speakers is remembering NOT to breathe out a /h/ sound. That is fairly easy to do, because English already has a few silent-h words (hour, honor). The only extra wrinkle is the linguistic distinction between “h muet” (allows liaison) and “h aspiré” (blocks liaison), but that does not change how you actually pronounce it—both are silent—so it is more a listening/grammar point than a pronunciation one.
description: In French, the letter “h” is never pronounced as an audible /h/ like in English “hat.” You simply start the next vowel or consonant without any burst of air. The mouth stays relaxed; no voiceless puff is made. Remember: silent, with or without liaison depending on the word, but always silent for pronunciation.

thoughts: French “gn” makes a single nasal sound [ɲ]—close to the Spanish ñ in “piñata” or the “ny” in English “canyon.” English speakers rarely pronounce this sound except in foreign names, so it may feel new; but they have probably seen it in words like “champagne” and “cognac.” Occasionally, mainly in scientific/Latin-based words (e.g., “diagnostic”), French still says it as two separate letters g+n, but the common everyday reading is the soft nasal [ɲ]. Clinch the tongue against the roof of the mouth as if starting an English “y,” while directing air through the nose.
description: Usually a single palatal nasal consonant [ɲ], like Spanish ñ or the “ny” in “canyon.” The tongue touches the roof just behind the teeth, air flows through the nose, and the following vowel starts immediately. Rarely, in learned or foreign words, it can still be pronounced “g + n.”

thoughts: In French, the digraph “ph” always represents the single consonant sound /f/, exactly like the first sound in English “fish.” English already uses the same spelling-to-sound rule in words such as “phone,” so nothing new to learn except remembering that it is never pronounced /p/ or /ph/—just a plain /f/.
description: Pronounce “ph” as a simple /f/ sound. Put your top teeth lightly on your bottom lip and push air out, the same way you pronounce the English letter “f.” Don’t add a puff of extra air and don’t try to voice it—keep it crisp and voiceless.

thoughts: English readers already see “qu” all the time, but in French it nearly always represents a simple /k/ sound with no following /w/. That surprises some beginners, yet the actual pronunciation is easy because English already has the /k/ consonant.

thoughts: English speakers already know the spelling “th,” but in French it is never the English TH sound. The h is silent and the digraph is pronounced exactly like a plain /t/. Learners just have to remember to shut off the English dental-fricative habit.

thoughts: “rh” never forms a new sound in French; the h is silent and you just pronounce the normal French R /ʁ/. The difficulty therefore is the uvular French R itself, not the presence of the h. It shows up mainly in Greek-origin words (rhum, rhinocéros, Rhône, etc.).
description: Say the regular French R (a voiced uvular fricative made at the back of the throat, somewhat like clearing your throat gently). The written h does NOTHING—you do not add an English H puff. If you can already do the French R, treat “rh” exactly the same.

thoughts: French “sh” is just the same /ʃ/ sound English speakers already know from “shoe.” It shows up mostly in modern loan-words, so learners will meet it in familiar contexts. Nothing new articulatorily; the only surprise is that native French spelling rarely uses it—French usually writes the same sound with “ch.”
description: Pronounce it exactly like the “sh” in English “shut.” Tongue is raised toward the roof just behind the alveolar ridge, lips rounded slightly. There is no vocal-cord vibration. If you can say English “sh,” you can say the French one.

thoughts: French “ss” is simply the un-voiced /s/ sound, like the English “s” in “hiss.” It is mainly used between vowels to guarantee the sound stays /s/ (a single “s” between vowels usually becomes /z/ in French). Because the sound itself exists in English, learners rarely struggle with it.
description: Pronounce it exactly like the sharp S in English “snake” or “kiss.” Keep the vocal cords off (no buzzing) – unlike the /z/ in English “rose.” If you see only one “s” between vowels in French, it usually turns into /z/, so the double “ss” is your visual cue to stick with the clear, hissy /s/.

thoughts: French “ll” can be either the ordinary clear L sound English speakers already know, or—when it follows the written letter i (ill/ille)—it often melts into a quick y-glide. Learners must remember some common exceptions (ville, mille, tranquille, etc.) where it stays a plain L.
description: Most of the time “ll” is pronounced just like a single English ‘l’.  BUT after the written letter i (and in a few words after e or a), “ill / ille / aille / eille” is pronounced like the English consonant Y in “yes.”  So “ville” = [l], but “famille” = fa-MEE-y.  Memorize the frequent exception group ending in “-ille” (ville, mille, tranquille, etc.) where you still say a clear L.

thoughts: “ill” is tricky because it has two main pronunciations: most of the time it turns into the English “y” glide /j/, but in a handful of common words it keeps a clear L sound. English speakers know the glide sound, but the switching rule is not obvious, so it causes confusion.
description:
1) Most often, especially after a vowel (fa-mille, Bas-tille), “ill” is pronounced like the English “y” in “yes.” It feels as if the tongue moves quickly from the vowel in front toward the front of the roof of the mouth. There is no audible L.
2) In a small set of frequent words—mainly those that already contain an i before the ll, such as ville, mille, tranquille—the L is pronounced. Say an English “eel” but keep it shorter and clearer: /il/.

thoughts: English speakers will have seen “ille” in French names like “famille” or the city “Lille,” but they rarely know that it can be said two different ways. The main hurdle is deciding when it is the y-glide /ij/ (famille) and when it is the clear L sound /il/ (ville). Otherwise the tongue and mouth positions are familiar: either just the long French i (/i/, close to the English “ee”) plus a quick English-like y, or a normal light French L.
description: Two common pronunciations: (1) Most of the time it sounds like “ee-y” run together /ij/, as in famille or vanille – imagine saying English “fee-yuh” but cut the uh; keep the tongue high then glide forward. (2) In a small group of very common words (ville, mille, tranquille, Lille) it is simply /il/, like the English word “eel” but shorter and lighter. Listen for native examples to know which group a word belongs to; there is no spelling change.

thoughts: Same spelling exists in English, so learners already ‘see’ it. In French it flips between two very ordinary sounds: /sk/ (as in English “ski”) and simple /s/ (as in “see”). The only thing to remember is that before the soft vowels e-i-y it loses the /k/. Nothing new has to be produced in the mouth, just recall when the K is silent.
description:

• Before e, i, y: pronounce it /s/ (often written phonetically /s/ or /sj/ in ‘sci-’), like the “s” in English “see”.
Tip: glance at the next vowel—if it’s a, o, u you keep the K, if it’s e, i, y you drop it.

It turns up mostly in words of foreign origin or in technical terms.  The sound itself is totally familiar to English speakers, but the unexpected spelling can slow them down.

thoughts: “tch” is pronounced exactly like the English “ch” in “chair.” French uses the same /tʃ/ affricate, and the spelling even appears in some English words (match, ketchup). So most English speakers already know both the spelling and the sound.

Lips are slightly rounded, tongue tip touches the ridge just behind the top teeth, then pulls back letting air hiss briefly.

thoughts: In French the letter pair “ps” has two main behaviors: (1) when it starts a word or sits inside one, both letters are usually pronounced /ps/, just like the last two sounds of the English word “lapse”; (2) when it ends certain common words, both letters often disappear from speech – you pronounce nothing at all after the preceding vowel or consonant. Because English never writes two letters that both go silent, learners have to memorize which French words drop the sound.
description: Inside or at the beginning of a word, say a quick “p” immediately followed by “s” (as in Eng. “oops” without the vowel). At the end of some short, very common words, neither the p nor the s is voiced – the word ends abruptly with the previous sound (e.g., corps = /kɔʁ/). There is no reliable spelling rule to predict the silent case, so it must be learned word-by-word.

thoughts: English already has the consonant cluster “pt” (apt, script, receipt). In French the letters work the same way when both are pronounced (/pt/), but very often the p is silent so only a /t/ is heard, especially at the end of a word like “sept.” The main thing to remember is to check if the p is said; otherwise, just pronounce a plain French /t/.
description:
“pt” can be pronounced two ways:
1. /pt/ – Both consonants pronounced, much like English “apt.” This happens inside many words (aptitude, rupture).
2. /t/ – The p is silent, so it sounds like a plain French t. Most common when the cluster ends the word (sept, prompt).
Keep the French /t/ soft (tongue against upper teeth) and, when the p is heard, release it quickly before the t, as in English “apt.”

thoughts: English speakers already meet “gue” in familiar loan-words like “vague” and “fatigue.” In French it simply guarantees a hard /g/ before the letter e; the u itself is silent. At the end of a word the whole group often collapses to just /g/. When a vowel sound follows (baguette, guérilla) you hear hard /g/ plus the normal French vowel value of the e that follows.
description: Pronounce a hard g, like the g in English “go.” The letter u is NOT pronounced; it only keeps the g hard before the front vowel e. If “gue” is at the very end of the word, you usually hear just /g/ with no vowel after it. If another vowel follows (baguette, guérilla) you say /g/ and then the French e sound.

thoughts: For English speakers, the digraph “ge” is almost always the “soft g” /ʒ/, the same sound as the “s” in “measure.”  The only challenge is remembering that the final –e is usually silent unless it carries an accent, and that the sound never becomes a hard /g/.  The sound itself exists in English, but its French spelling can feel counter-intuitive.
description: In French, the letters g + e spell the single consonant /ʒ/ (like the “zh” in English ‘measure’ or ‘vision’).  If the e is plain and word-final, it is normally silent (rouge /ʁuʒ/).  If the e is accented (gé, gè, gén-), you hear both the /ʒ/ and the vowel value of the accented e (génie /ʒe/ or /ʒe.ni/).  The sound is never the hard /g/ of English ‘get.’  Keep the tongue relaxed and place the tip just behind the bottom front teeth while the middle of the tongue makes a narrow channel for the voiced air to buzz.

thoughts: Two main French pronunciations: open [ɛ] (“eh”) when followed by a consonant or in a closed syllable; closed [e] (“ay”) when it ends a syllable/word, especially in verb forms. description: Most of the time “ais” is pronounced /ɛ/ – an open “eh” like the e in “bed,” but held a touch longer and without any ending glide. thoughts: Word-final “ai” in French is usually pronounced as one of the two short ‘e’ vowels: the closed /e/ (similar to the vowel in the English word “say,” but without the off-glide toward a ‘y’ sound) or the open /ɛ/ (like the first part of “bet,” but a touch tenser). thoughts: English speakers usually guess “ais” the way they read “aisle” or “raise” – a long AY sound plus a pronounced S. description: At the end of a French word, “ais” is pronounced roughly like the English short “e” in “bet” (/ɛ/); the final S is normally silent. description: Usually pronounced /o/ (pure ‘oh’). Before r it is /ɔ/ (‘aw’ as in ‘law’). Keep lips rounded; do not let the sound slide toward ‘w’.

thoughts: English speakers have no native front-rounded vowels, so the French digraph “eu” feels unfamiliar. It is usually pronounced either as a closed /ø/ (lips rounded, tongue like English long “a” in ‘day’ but further forward) or as a more open /œ/ (similar tongue position to English “uh” in ‘cup’, but with rounded lips). Hold the lips rounded the whole time; don’t glide to “oo.”

• Closed /ø/ – longer, tenser, often in stressed, word-final, or open-syllable positions (eu, peu, bleu).
• Open /œ/ – shorter, laxer, often before pronounced consonants (fleur, neuf, heure).
Think of saying English “uh” while whistling: keep the front of the tongue up and lips rounded.

description: œu is pronounced as a rounded version of the English "uh/er" sound in "her," but with the lips pushed forward and rounded like when you say “oo.” It can be slightly more closed /ø/ (as in bleu) or more open /œ/ (as in bœuf), but both keep that front-rounded quality. No exact English equivalent exists, so imagine saying “eh” while shaping the lips for “oo.”

thoughts: ‘ui’ is quite common in French. When it stands alone (lui, nuit, etc.) it sounds like a single syllable that starts with the tight-lipped ‘y’ glide /ɥ/ and slides straight into the English “ee.” It feels a bit like saying English “wee” while keeping your lips more rounded and pushed forward. However, when the letters follow q or g (quiche, guitare) the u is only there to tell you how to pronounce the consonant; the actual vowel you hear is just /i/ as in English “see.” English speakers know words such as “oui,” “Louis Vuitton,” and “quiche,” but the /ɥ/ glide itself does not exist in English, so producing it can be tricky.
description: Most of the time ‘ui’ is pronounced in a single beat as /ɥi/ – imagine saying English “wee” but with your lips puckered as if you are starting to whistle. After q or g, the u is silent and you simply hear /i/ (“kee” or “gee”).

thoughts: “ue” in French does two very different jobs. 1) After most consonants it simply spells the vowel /y/ (the very front-rounded French “u”); the final “e” is silent and just tells you to pronounce the preceding “u” as a vowel. 2) After the letters g or q (as in “gue / que”) the “u” is silent – it only protects the hard /g/ or /k/ sound before the front vowel “e”.  English speakers already bump into both spellings in loan-words like “statue” or “Cirque du Soleil”, so the pattern feels familiar, but producing the French /y/ still takes practice.
description:
Two main pronunciations:
• /y/ (French front-rounded "u") when “ue” appears on its own at the end of a syllable: rue /ʁy/, statue /sta.ty/.  Think of saying English “ee” while rounding your lips.
• Silent “u” after g or q: it just keeps the consonant hard, so “cirque” sounds like “sirk”.  English has no real equivalent, so remember the “u” isn’t heard.

thoughts: “ie” is fairly common in French.  Sometimes it is a straight long “ee” sound (/i/), very close to the English vowel in “see.”  Other times, especially right after a consonant, it turns into a quick English-style “y” glide plus an open “eh” (/jɛ/ or /je/), something like the start of “yes” followed by the “e” in “bed.”  English speakers have heard both versions in food names and basic phrases, but may mix them up because English spelling never uses “ie” this way.
description: Two main values: (1) /i/ – a pure long “ee” as in English “see,” used at the ends of words such as “Brie” or “copie.”  (2) /jɛ/ (or /je/) – a quick “y” glide plus open “eh,” heard after a consonant before another consonant or a silent final letter, e.g., “pied” or “bien.”  Keep the glide very short and the final vowel open, not the tense English ‘ay.’

thoughts: “em” is one of those French spellings that can sound either like the English “ehm” in “hem” or like a nasalized “ahn” that English doesn’t really have. thoughts: Two separate French pronunciations: (1) nasal vowel /ɛ̃/ when “im” is before another consonant (usually p, b, m) and the m itself is NOT pronounced; (2) regular oral /im/ when the m is doubled, followed by a vowel, or at the very end of the word. 2. Oral version – /im/: Just like the English word “eam” in “team,” with a clear m at the end. You get this when the m is doubled (immigration), followed by a vowel (imagine), or closes the word (crime).

English has no nasal vowels, so learners tend to either drop the nasal quality or pronounce a full n, but the mouth shape is otherwise familiar.
description: Usually pronounced as one nasal vowel /ɛ̃/: start like the English “eh” in “men,” lower the jaw slightly, then let the sound resonate through the nose and do NOT release an audible n. If a vowel follows (liaison), pronounce an open /ɛ/ + light n instead of nasalizing.

example_words.cultural_context: ‘Bread’—seen on bakery signs or in the phrase “pain au chocolat.”
Popular chocolate-filled pastry on café menus.
Famous fashion house and Paris metro stop (Yves Saint Laurent).
Culinary term for a hot-water bath used in cooking and baking.

thoughts: “aim” can give English learners two different French sounds. 1️⃣  When the letters a-i-m are followed by another vowel (aimer, Aimé, j’aime) the group is NOT nasal – you pronounce the m clearly and the ai is an “eh” sound. 2️⃣  When a-i-m is at the end of a word or before another consonant (faim) the m and the preceding vowel fuse into the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/, a sound English doesn’t have in normal words.
description:
Two possibilities:
• Non-nasal: If “aim” is followed by a vowel, say “eh” as in English “bet”, then a clear m: /ɛm/ (j’aime /ʒɛm/).
• Nasal: If “aim” ends the word or is before another consonant, make the front “eh” vowel while letting air escape through your nose and do NOT finish with an audible m: /ɛ̃/ (faim /fɛ̃/). Think of starting to say “end” but stop before the n forms, all while humming through your nose.

example_words.cultural_context: The phrase “je t’aime” appears in countless songs and movies
Seen in the fashion brand “Aimé Leon Dore” and in French names like Aimé Césaire
Used in the textbook phrase “j’ai faim” (“I’m hungry”) in beginner French

thoughts: “ein” spells the French nasal vowel /ɛ̃/. It can occur anywhere in a word, so I mark overall position as “Anywhere.” English has no true nasal vowels, so learners must learn to let the air resonate in the nose while keeping the mouth in the open-“eh” position. The most accessible French words with the exact letters e-i-n are “Seine,” “plein,” and “peinture.” These are reasonably familiar to many English speakers through geography, art terms, or museum labels.
description: Pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/: start with an English “eh” as in “bet,” but lower the jaw slightly and let air escape through the nose without adding an ending n sound. Do NOT pronounce a hard n; the n just makes the preceding vowel nasal.

example_words.cultural_context: River that flows through Paris, often mentioned in travel shows and books
Heard in the art phrase “en plein air,” meaning painting outdoors
French word for painting—commonly seen on museum placards and art discussions

thoughts: The spelling “e i m” is rare but when it does occur in French it works just like the more common spellings “ain/aim/ein/in” : it signals the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/. English has no nasal vowels, but learners usually meet this sound in words like “vin” or “pain,” so it won’t be totally new, just written in an unexpected way.
description: eim is pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/: start with the English short “e” in “bet,” then lower your soft palate so air also escapes through your nose, and don’t let your lips close for an m-sound—the m just tells you to nasalize the vowel. It never sounds like an actual “m” unless another vowel follows.

example_words.cultural_context: Well-known Champagne city; heard in travel shows and WWII history

thoughts: “on” represents the nasal vowel /ɔ̃/. English has no true nasal vowels, so learners must remember not to release an audible n at the end.
description: Pronounced as one nasal vowel, roughly like the vowel in British “aw” (lawn) but with air also flowing through the nose and with NO n-sound after it. Round your lips, lower the soft palate, and cut the vowel off cleanly.

example_words.cultural_context: French word for “hello,” heard in movies and travel
Common cooking-show phrase meaning “enjoy your meal”
Trendy French almond cookie sold in many bakeries
Well-known Canadian city, often anglicized as Montreal

thoughts: “om” is common in French; it can either stay a normal o-plus-m sound (when another vowel follows the m) or turn into the nasal vowel /ɔ̃/ (similar to the o in “song” but without the g) when the m is followed by another consonant or nothing at all. English speakers have heard both versions in food, fashion and brand names, so the sound is familiar, but the nasal version still needs practice.
description:
Two possibilities:
1) Nasal /ɔ̃/: the lips start to round as for a short open “aw” (as in British “cot”), while air escapes partly through the nose and the m itself is NOT pronounced. This happens when “om” is at the end of a syllable or before another consonant (nom, ombré, Dom).
2) Non-nasal /ɔm/: a plain o sound plus a clear m, just like the English word “om”, when the m is followed by a written vowel (omelette, homme).

example_words.cultural_context: Classic French egg dish found on breakfast menus everywhere
Seen in the phrase “nom de plume” meaning pen name
Used in fragrance names like “YSL L’Homme”
Popular hair-coloring technique and fashion term

thoughts: French “un” is usually read as the nasal vowel /œ̃/—your mouth starts to make an English “uh” but, before you fully voice it, you let the sound resonate up behind the nose while keeping lips loosely rounded. No actual n-sound is released; the tongue stays low. It can occur at the start, middle, or end of a word whenever the letters u n are followed by a consonant or are word-final.
description: Pronounce it as a nasalized, slightly rounded “uh,” similar to the vowel in English “sun” but with the airflow also passing through the nose and without finishing with an /n/. Keep the mouth relaxed and don’t close the lips or tongue for an n.

example_words.cultural_context: Basic French word for “a/one,” seen in phrases like “un café”
French word for Monday—often printed on bilingual calendars or schedules
Same spelling as English “jungle”; title of the famous book “Le Livre de la jungle” (The Jungle Book)
Word for a mixed drink; appears on French cocktail menus and is cognate with English “punch”

thoughts: French “um” flips between two very different pronunciations. 1) In many everyday French words (parfum, humble) the letters signal a nasal vowel—no audible m. 2) In scholarly/Latin loan-words (maximum, forum) the vowel is an open “aw” sound followed by an audible m. English speakers know the words but not the sound rules, so they often pronounce the m when it should be silent or use the wrong vowel quality.
description:
Two main options:
• Nasal /œ̃/ (close to the French sound in “un”). Lips start to round for an English “uh”, then lower the velum so air leaks through the nose; do NOT voice an m. Happens before b/p/m or at word-end in many native French words.
• Oral /ɔm/ (like British “o” in “lot” + m) in learned Latin words such as maximum, forum. Here the m is fully pronounced.
Remember: if the word looks Latin or scientific, say /ɔm/; otherwise suspect the silent-m nasal.

example_words.cultural_context: Same spelling in English; adjective meaning modest
Seen on perfume bottles as part of “eau de parfum”
Math/science term identical to English word

thoughts: “yn” is written exactly like the English letters y-n, but in French it works as one unit: it creates the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/ (the same sound you hear in French “vin” or “pain”). English has no true nasal vowels, so learners must say an “eh” sound while letting the air resonate in the nose and cutting the tongue off before an audible n is released.
description: Pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/: start with an English “eh” (as in “set”), then let the sound vibrate in your nose and stop before letting the tongue finish an n. Do NOT pronounce a separate y or n.

example_words.cultural_context: Same medical term used in English
Famous explosive; word exists in English
Wild cat species; spelling is identical in English
Academic word related to “synthesis,” recognizable to English speakers

thoughts: In French, the sequence “ym” almost always signals the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/, the same sound heard in in/yn/ain/ien. English has no nasal vowels, so learners tend to let air escape only through the mouth; they must relax the jaw, raise the back of the tongue toward the soft palate, and let some air flow out the nose while keeping the lips parted. If another vowel follows the m, the sound is no longer nasal: you pronounce /im/ + vowel instead. This second case is rare in common words.
description: Most of the time “ym” = the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/ (something like the vowel in French “vin”) followed by no audible m. If a vowel immediately follows, pronounce /im/ plus that vowel (no nasalization).

example_words.cultural_context: Almost identical to English “symbol” – familiar term in art, math, etc.
Common casual word you may see in social media or heard in movies meaning “nice/cool”
Looks like English “sympathetic,” appears in travel guides and subtitles

thoughts: “oin” is one of French’s nasal vowel groups. English has no true nasal vowels, so the sound will feel new. It is written o-i-n but is pronounced as a single nasal vowel that glides from an “w”-like start to a nasalized “eh” ([wɛ̃]). You do not pronounce the n; instead let air resonate in your nose while your mouth moves as if saying the English word “when”, but keep it very short and nasal, starting with rounded lips.
description: Pronounce it as one nasal vowel [wɛ̃]: start with lips rounded as if saying “w” then quickly open toward a short “eh”, letting sound escape through the nose. There is no separate n sound.

Surname of famous mathematician/physicist Henri Poincaré
Spelled like the English word “coin”; means “corner” in French

thoughts: French “oin” is always pronounced /wɛ̃/: first a quick English-style w-glide, then a nasal version of the vowel in “bet,” with no audible n at the end. English has no direct match, so learners must master both the nasal airflow and dropping the final n.
description: Start with a brief w-sound, then move into an ‘eh’ vowel while letting air resonate through the nose. Keep the vowel short, rounded, and do NOT say an n afterward.

example_words.cultural_context: Spelled like English “coin” (money); seen on bilingual signs and basic vocab lists
Looks like the English cut of meat “loin”; common in the phrase “loin de” (“far from”)
Part of the beginner phrase “j’ai besoin de…” (“I need…”)

thoughts: English speakers already meet the letters “ent”, but in French the ending behaves very differently: it is either completely silent (verb ending) or turns into the nasal vowel /ɑ̃/. That nasal vowel has no final n-sound, which can surprise learners. The silent version is conceptually easy (just don’t say it), but remembering when it is silent vs. nasal and actually producing a clean French nasal vowel is moderately challenging.
description:
At the very end of a French word, -ent is usually NOT pronounced the way it looks:
1. In 3rd-person plural verb forms (ils parlent, ils prennent), the letters are totally silent – you jump straight from the preceding consonant or vowel to the final pause.
2. In nouns, adjectives, names, etc., -ent is pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɑ̃/ – roughly like an English “ah” said while the back of your tongue is lowered and air also escapes through the nose; do not add an audible n or t.

example_words.cultural_context: Same word as English “agent” – e.g., secret agent
Famous given name (Vincent van Gogh, actor Vincent Price)
English speakers know the word “comment” on websites; in French it means “how/what”

thoughts: Final “e” in French is the well-known “silent e.” English already has a silent e, so the concept is familiar; the difference is that French never turns it into an /ei/ sound or lengthens the vowel—it’s simply dropped. English speakers’ main trap is to give it a full vowel (e.g., “bag-ETT-ee”). Once they remember to end on the last consonant, the sound is easy.
description: A single, unaccented “e” at the very end of a French word is normally silent. You stop after the last pronounced consonant (ba-“gett,” fro-“mahj”). In slow, formal speech or singing it can surface as a very short, relaxed schwa /ə/, but in everyday conversation you don’t voice it at all.

French word for cheese—seen on ‘cheese & charcuterie’ menus
Common French title equivalent to “Mrs.” or polite “ma’am”
Same spelling as English ‘table’; used in beginner French classes

thoughts: Final “-es” in French is either totally silent or sounds like a pure “ay” (/e/). English speakers already meet it in names like “Cannes” and articles like “les”. Remember: you never pronounce the final S.
description: At the very end of a word, ‑es usually drops away completely; you finish on the consonant right before it (Cannes → “kan”). When the whole word is just three letters (les, des, mes, etc.) you do pronounce the vowel as the tight French /e/—similar to the English word “say” without the Y glide—but the S is still silent.

example_words.cultural_context: Famous French Riviera city with its international film festival
Plural article heard in the title “Les Misérables”
Common French word meaning “some”, shows up in menus like “salade des fruits”

thoughts: English speakers already know the letter “s”, but in French its behavior at the END of a word is unpredictable: often silent, sometimes /s/, and in liaison it can even sound like /z/. They need to un-learn the reflex of always pronouncing it.
description: At the very end of a French word, a single “s” is USUALLY silent (Paris → “pa-REE”). In some short words or borrowed terms it keeps the unvoiced English /s/ sound (très, bus). When the next word starts with a vowel, the normally silent “s” can link and become the voiced /z/ (vous avez → /vu-za-vé/). So: final s = silent, /s/, or liaison /z/. Same mouth shape as English “s” or “z”, just remember when to drop it.

Seen in the fashion phrase “très chic” meaning “very”
Same word for public transport vehicle

thoughts: Final x in French is usually silent, but in a handful of short words—mostly the numbers six and dix—it is pronounced like an un-voiced English “s.” In liaison before a following vowel it can become a “z” sound, but learners first meet it as either silent or /s/. English speakers are used to silent final letters (e.g., ‘ballet’) but may over-pronounce x because of the English habit of saying /ks/.
description: At the end of most French words, the letter x is NOT pronounced at all (e.g., Bordeaux → bor-DOH). In a few very short words, mainly the numbers six and dix, it is pronounced like the English “s” in “see” (/sis/ or /dis/). If the next word begins with a vowel, this /s/ can change to a soft “z.” Importantly, you never say the English /ks/ sound at the end of a French word.

thoughts: English speakers usually pronounce every written final “t,” but French usually drops it unless the word is very short or clearly borrowed from English/tech terms. Learners must learn to ignore the written t most of the time yet keep it in a few common exceptions such as “internet.”
description: At the end of a French word, “t” is normally silent (you stop your voice but do not release a burst of air). Think of the final sound in French “ballet” – you do NOT hear a /t/. A pronounced final t only shows up in a handful of brief function-words (est, ouest, huit) or obvious modern loans like “internet,” where it sounds like the normal English /t/. So your default rule: don’t say the t unless you are sure the word is an exception.

thoughts: Final ‑d is one of those French letters that often exists only on paper. Most of the time you do NOTHING with it, but in a handful of very short words you pronounce it just like the normal English /d/. Learners mainly have to remember when to stay silent.
description: At the end of a French word the letter d is usually silent (you stop on the preceding vowel or nasal sound). Think of it as the English word “cold” but you simply don’t release the final /d/. A few short words—especially “sud” and some proper names like “David”—do pronounce a clear, soft English-style /d/. If the next word starts with a vowel and a liaison is required, the silent d turns into a /t/ sound, but in everyday isolated words you can ignore it.

Means “hot”; English speakers meet it in “vin chaud” (mulled wine) or “pain au chocolat chaud”

Common first name; pronounced with the final /d/ in French as in English

thoughts: Final -p in French is usually silent, but some short or borrowed words do pronounce it. The sound itself is the same un-aspirated /p/ an English speaker already knows; the challenge is remembering when not to say it.
description: At the very end of a French word, the letter p is most often mute, e.g. coup → /ku/. When it IS pronounced (mainly in short words or English borrowings like stop), it’s the same un-aspirated p you hear in the English word “spin” (no puff of air). So: hear it in stop, ignore it in coup.

example_words.cultural_context: You meet it in news phrases like “coup d’état” for a political overthrow
Common slang in phrases like “trop cool” (‘so cool’) seen on social media and T-shirts
French road signs literally read “STOP”; same word as in English and the final p is pronounced

thoughts: Final ‑g is one of those letters English speakers ‘see but rarely hear’ in French.  In most native French words (long, sang) the g itself disappears; the preceding n simply becomes the velar nasal /ŋ/, so the result sounds a lot like the “ng” in English song.  In more recent borrowings from English (blog, tag, ping-pong) French keeps the hard g /g/ you already know.  Learners therefore have to decide: older words = no audible g; recent loan-words = pronounce the hard g.
description: At the very end of a word, g is usually silent; the n before it turns into the nasal /ŋ/, giving a sound like the ng in English “song.”  In modern loan-words and abbreviations, the final g is pronounced as a hard g /g/, identical to the g in English “dog.”  So: native word → no burst of g; imported or trendy word → pronounce the hard g.

Same word as in English for an online journal
Table-tennis game; borrowed intact from English

thoughts: French words that end in the letter “z” are usually pronounced in one of two ways: (1) the final z is completely silent, or (2) it is pronounced as the voiced English z sound /z/.  English speakers already know the /z/ sound, but they have to remember that very often the written z simply disappears in French.  Well-known loan-words like “jazz” and basic function words like “chez” conveniently illustrate both cases.
description: Most French words ending in “z” drop the consonant entirely (chez = /ʃe/).  When the z is pronounced, it is the same voiced z sound as in English “zoo” (gaz = /gaz/, jazz = /ʒaz/).  No aspiration or vowel change—just a clean /z/ or nothing at all.  Knowing whether to pronounce it comes down to memorizing the individual word; the silent pattern is more common.

thoughts: English speakers see “ps-” in words like “psychology” but usually drop the p. In French, the p is actually pronounced, so learners must get used to starting a word with the consonant cluster /ps/. The cluster never changes: both consonants are said quickly with no vowel between.
description: In French, the letters p + s at the very start of a word are both pronounced: a short, unaspirated /p/ released straight into /s/ (like the end of the English word “lips,” but moved to the front of the word). Do NOT silence the p as in English “psychology.” Close the lips for /p/, then let air pass immediately for /s/ without inserting a vowel.

thoughts: Initial ‘pt-’ in French keeps BOTH consonants, unlike English where the p is silent. English speakers therefore have to learn to release a very quick /p/ immediately followed by /t/ with no vowel in between.
description: Say a light /p/ and /t/ back-to-back with no vowel break: lips pop open for /p/, tongue tip touches the ridge right after for /t/. It feels a bit like starting to say “apt” but without the leading vowel. English usually drops the /p/ in similar Greek words (pterodactyl), so remember that French doesn’t.

thoughts: French “gn” at the very start of a word is always the single palatal-nasal sound /ɲ/, the same consonant written “ñ” in Spanish. English has the mouth movement only inside words (ca-nyon, o-ni-on), never at the beginning, so the placement feels unusual.
description: Say an English “n” while the middle of your tongue is pressed high against the hard palate, as if you were starting the word “nyah.” There is no separate “g” sound—just one smooth, buzzing nasal consonant like Spanish “ñ.”
